actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on March 20, 2024.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mrs. Cammack moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 390
actions-list.actionItem: 9 (Roll no. 88).
Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 149 — "Condemning the illegal abduction of children from Ukraine to the Russian Federation."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 365
actions-list.actionItem: 30 (Roll no. 87).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4723 — "To provide for the imposition of sanctions with respect to foreign persons undermining the Dayton Peace Agreement or threatening the security of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 19.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 6:30 P.M. today.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting the Budget Message for FY 2025
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Appropriations and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-96).

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7520.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mrs. Rodgers (WA) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 7520 — "To prohibit data brokers from transferring sensitive data of United States individuals to foreign adversaries, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1836.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Johnson (SD) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1836 — "To amend title 46, United States Code, to make technical corrections with respect to ocean shipping authorities, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6261.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Johnson (SD) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6261 — "To direct the Comptroller General to conduct a review on the impact of crime on public building usage, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6260.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Johnson (SD) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6260 — "To provide for certain reviews of the use and safety of Federal buildings, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 766.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Burgess moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 766 — "To amend the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 respecting the scoring of preventive health savings."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6602.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. McCormick moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6602 — "To amend the Export Control Reform Act of 2018 relating to the review of the interagency dispute resolution process."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 149.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mrs. Wagner moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended. H. Res. 149 — "Condemning the illegal abduction of children from Ukraine to the Russian Federation."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6610.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mrs. Wagner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6610 — "To provide for the modernization of the passport issuance process, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4723.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mrs. Wagner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 4723 — "To provide for the imposition of sanctions with respect to foreign persons undermining the Dayton Peace Agreement or threatening the security of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and for other purposes."
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6306.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mrs. Wagner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6306 — "To amend the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 to prohibit the acquisition or lease of a consular or diplomatic post built or owned by an entity beneficially owned by the People's Republic of China, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 19.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mrs. Miller-Meeks to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 19.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Anthony D'Esposito to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
